thread.title: Darnell Ferrell's big accomplishment decisive moment for Central Catholic
thread.title_full: Darnell Ferrell's big accomplishment decisive moment for Central Catholic

title: Darnell Ferrell's big accomplishment decisive moment for Central Catholic
text:
Darnell Ferrell accomplished three things with his 69-yard touchdown run in the first quarter of Central Catholic’s 48-27 hammering of Nazareth in an Eastern Pennsylvania Conference South Division football game Saturday afternoon at a sun-splashed J. Birney Crum Stadium. 
First, the Viking junior running back put his team ahead 21-0. 
Second, the play was part of a sequence that probably marked the point of no return as far as the Blue Eagles’ chance for a win went. 
And third, it served as a human silencer. 
“(Nazareth) had been talking trash about us all week,” Ferrell said. “We heard it all week.” 
The only thing heard at the end of Ferrell’s decisive run was the roaring of Central’s delighted Homecoming crowd. 
The play was a speed sweep designed to take advantage of Ferrell’s ability to outrun defenders even if they had angles on him. 
“We’ve been working all fall on setting up the blocking for that play,” said Ferrell, who wound up with 91 yards on four carries, said. “That’s my first big one, my first big run like that.” 
It wasn’t just big – it was huge. 
The Vikings (4-2, 3-2 EPC South) led 14-0 and had just stopped a Nazareth drive thanks to a Tom Murphy interception. 
Ferrell’s epic run followed on the next play and Central Catholic rode that momentum the rest of the way. 
“It was a really, really good feeling running alone to the end zone,” Ferrell said. “Once I saw Alvin hit his lead block, I knew I was gone.” 
Alvin? Senior Alvin Pacheco , he of the 234 yards and four touchdowns Saturday? Blocking? 
“They block for me,” Pacheco said. “I block for them.” 
No one wonder Ferrell, Pacheco and the rest of the Vikings accomplished what they did Saturday.
